factoid: Sophie is the youngest princess with a mole.
Sophie is rosy and laughter-loving.
Sophie watched Pierre.
Sophie smiled.
Sophie hid her face in her handkerchief.
Sophie remained with her face hidden for a while.
Sophie looked up and saw Pierre.
Sophie began to laugh again.
Sophie felt unable to look at Pierre without laughing.
Sophie could not resist looking at Pierre.
Sophie slipped quietly behind one of the columns to avoid temptation.
During the service, the voices of the priests suddenly ceased.
The priests whispered to one another.
The old servant was holding the count’s hand.
The old servant got up and said something to the ladies.
Anna Mikháylovna stepped forward.
Anna Mikháylovna stooped over the dying man.
Anna Mikháylovna beckoned to Lorrain from behind her back.
The French doctor held no taper.
The French doctor was leaning against one of the columns in a respectful attitude.
The French doctor was a foreigner.
The French doctor understood the full importance of the rite being performed.
The French doctor approved of the rite.
The French doctor approached the sick man with a noiseless step.
The French doctor had full vigor of life.
The French doctor had delicate white fingers raised from the green quilt.
The French doctor felt the pulse of the sick man.
The sick man was given something to drink.
There was a stir around the sick man.
The people resumed their places.
The service continued.
Pierre noticed that Prince Vasili had left the chair he had been leaning on.
Prince Vasili did not go up to the dying man.
Prince Vasili passed by the dying man.
Prince Vasili joined the eldest princess.
Prince Vasili moved with the eldest princess to the side of the room where stood the high bedstead with its silken hangings.
Prince Vasili and the eldest princess passed out by a back door.
Prince Vasili and the eldest princess returned to their places one after the other before the service was concluded.
Pierre paid no more attention to this occurrence than to the rest of what went on.
Pierre had made up his mind that what he saw happening around him that evening was in some way essential.
The chanting of the service ceased.
The voice of the priest was heard respectfully congratulating the dying man on having received the sacrament.
The dying man lay lifeless and immovable as before.
Around the dying man everyone began to stir.
Steps were audible and whispers.
Anna Mikháylovna’s whispers were the most distinct.
Pierre heard Anna Mikháylovna say, "Certainly he must be moved onto the bed; here it will be impossible..."
The sick man was surrounded by doctors, princesses, and servants.
Pierre could no longer see the reddish-yellow face with its gray mane.
Pierre had not lost sight of the reddish-yellow face for a single moment during the whole service.
Pierre judged by the cautious movements of those who crowded round the invalid chair that they had lifted the dying man and were moving him.
A servant said, "Catch hold of my arm or you’ll drop him!"
Another servant said, "Catch hold from underneath. Here!"
The heavy breathing of the bearers and the shuffling of their feet grew more hurried.
The bearers were carrying a weight that was too much for them.
Pierre caught a momentary glimpse between their heads and backs of the dying man’s high, stout, uncovered chest and powerful shoulders.
The dying man’s chest was raised by those who were holding him under the armpits.
The dying man’s gray, curly, leonine head was seen.
The head had a remarkably broad brow and cheekbones.
The head had a handsome, sensual mouth.
The head had a cold, majestic expression.
The head was not disfigured by the approach of death.
The head was the same as Pierre remembered it three months before.
The count had sent Pierre to Petersburg.
The head was swaying helplessly with the uneven movements of the bearers.
The head’s cold listless gaze fixed itself upon nothing.
